comment.author: 31846825@N04
comment._content: Accompanying note: "Long lines like this one are common in City Hall these days as an average of more than 200 people a day register to vote in the February City elections. So far this week about 835 people have registered. Yesterday alone 245 registered."
comment.authorname: State Library and Archives of Florida

comment.author: 25767425@N02
comment._content: Why not European-Ameicans? Or blacks and whites? Otherwise that title is weird.

comment.author: 97368839@N04
comment._content: Did not know that black people were aloud to vote in the 50's in Florida.I'm from the north.

comment.author: 35607158@N06
comment._content: This is not the least interesting of many interesting images in this wonderful set. It is perhaps a reminder that the history of voting rights (and race relations in the South generally) was not entirely a history of violent conflict and confrontation. Yes their was  a struggle but yes a great of what happened happened quietly and no not everyone's heart was stained by ill-will. It also reminds us that, like the history of the franchise for women, we know more about national and state level changes than we do about municipal and school board etc. level voting practices.

comment.author: 31846825@N04
comment._content: This particular scene reflects increased African American voter turnout during/after the Tallahassee Bus Boycott of 1956-57. See and read more on Florida Memory: floridamemory.com/onlineclassroom/civilrights/.
comment.authorname: State Library and Archives of Florida
